bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Jose R. Andreu to Philip Showalter Hench, [April 24, 1947]

div1.p: Andreu informs Hench that Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear has been declared a Cuban national monument. He emphasizes that the Yellow Fever Commission was working to prove Finlay's theory of mosquito transmission. He appreciates the efforts at mutual relations between Cuba and the United States and the Americans' recognition of Finlay's work.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Jose R. Andreu to Philip Showalter Hench, [April 24, 1947] See Spanish original.
div1.opener:
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
From: The Minister of Public Health and Social Assistance
Doctor Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Distinguished doctor:
div1.p:
In the files of this office I have found a letter from
you addressed to Doctor Jose A. Presno on December 19, 1944, at
the time in which he was occupying the position of Head of the
Public Service and Social Assistance.

I have the pleasure of taking this opportunity to inform
you that the Council of Ministers have agreed to declare a national
monument the small house in the district of Quemados in Marianao
where the American Commission worked to prove the theory of
Doctor Finlay about the transmission of yellow fever by the mos-
quito. I am the author of that motion.

I am very pleased with your initiative of collection
some money to make the historic place more beautiful--that is of
such scientific interest to preserve the place in which a bunch
of noble men sacrificed themselves in the interest of others.

I appreciate the circumstances as an effort of mutual
relations between the United States and Cuba and the discovery of
Finlay by the American Commission.
